Therefore, the code can be written as:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    return *(int*)a - *(int*)b;
}

int main() {
    int n;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    int size = 3 * n;
    int array[size];
    for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
        scanf("%d", &array[i]);
    }
    
    // First step processing
    qsort(array, size, sizeof(int), compare);
    int head = size - 2;
    long long res = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        res += array[head];
        head -= 2;
    }
    
    // Second step processing
    // Convert res to string
    char buffer[20];
    sprintf(buffer, "%lld", res);
    char *token = strtok(buffer, " ");
    int count = 0;
    while (token != NULL) {
        count++;
        if (strcmp(token, "0") == 0) break;
        token = strtok(NULL, " ");
    }
    
    // Third step processing
    int x = count;
    bool bool_val = (x == 1);
    int result = !bool_val ? 1 : 0;
    printf("%d\n", result);
    
    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the second step's processing, the count is the number of elements until the first "0".

count is incremented by 1. 

Then, if the token is "0", break. 

So the count is 1 if the token is "0" or not. 

So the count is always 1. 

Therefore, the third step's x is 1. 

Thus, the third step's result is 0. 

Therefore, the code will output 0. 

But the code above is correct.

So the code can be simplified:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

int compare(const void *a, const void *b) {
    return *(int*)a - *(int*)b;
}

int main() {
    int n;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    int size = 3 * n;
    int array[size];
    for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
        scanf("%d", &array[i]);
    }
    
    // First step processing
    qsort(array, size, sizeof(int), compare);
    int head = size - 2;
    long long res = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        res += array[head];
        head -= 2;
    }
    
    // Second step's output is always 1
    int count = 1;
    
    // Third step processing
    int x = count;
    bool bool_val = (x == 1);
    int result = !bool_val ? 1 : 0;
    printf("%d\n", result);
    
    return 0;
}
